=== Running Ubuntu One in Headless Mode ===

1. Install ubuntuone-client package: <pre>
   $ sudo apt-get install ubuntuone-client </pre>

2. Setup the user directories: <pre>
   $ mkdir -p ~/.config/ubuntuone ~/bin </pre>
   If you had no ~/bin directory, you will need to update your PATH or relogin: <pre>
   $ export PATH=$HOME/bin:$PATH </pre>

3. Obtain OAuth key for your account: <pre>
   $ cd /tmp
   $ wget http://people.canonical.com/~roman.yepishev/us/ubuntuone-sso-login.py
   $ python ubuntuone-sso-login.py
   Ubuntu SSO Login: **your Ubuntu SSO Login**
   Password: **your Ubuntu SSO Password**
   oauth=hPQWPsH:rhOokmNiRuuoiHe... </pre>

4. The line starting `oauth=` will be made of four separate colon-separated sections like `aaaa:bbbb:cccc:dddd`. Take the `cccc:dddd` part and add to `~/.config/ubuntuone/syncdaemon.conf` as the `oauth` parameter under ```__main__``` section (this is ini-style file): <pre>
   [__main__]
   oauth=hPQWPsH:rhOokmNiRuuoiHe... </pre>

5. Download the u1sdtool wrapper which will start dbus when needed. By default Ubuntu adds ~/bin/ to your path, so when you run u1sdtool, you will be running the wrapper. <pre>
   $ wget http://people.canonical.com/~roman.yepishev/us/u1sdtool-wrapper -O ~/bin/u1sdtool
   $ chmod +x ~/bin/u1sdtool </pre>

6. Start Ubuntu One, check Ubuntu One status and connect (starting from Oneiric Ubuntu One is connecting automatically when started): <pre>
   $ u1sdtool --start
   $ u1sdtool --status
   State: READY
      connection: Not User With Network
      description: ready to connect
      is_connected: False
      is_error: False
      is_online: False
      queues: IDLE
   $ u1sdtool --connect </pre>

7. Start adding files to ~/Ubuntu One directory and use <nowiki>[[..-u1sdtool|u1sdtool]]</nowiki> to add UDF, publish the files etc.
